definition:
Let $G$ be a group.

A *descending series* of $G$ is a family $(H_\alpha)_{\alpha\le\beta}$
of subgroups of $G$, where $\beta$ is an ordinal, such that $H_0=G$ and
$H_\beta=\{1\}$, and $H_{\alpha+1}\normal H_\alpha$ for all
$\alpha<\beta$, and $$\bigcap_{\alpha<\delta}H_\alpha=H_\delta$$
whenever $\delta\le\beta$ is a limit ordinal.

Note that this is a generalization of the concept of a subnormal series.
Compare also the dual concept of an ascending series.

Given a descending series $(H_\alpha)_{\alpha\le\beta}$, the subgroups
$H_\alpha$ are called the *terms* of the series and the
$H_\alpha/H_{\alpha+1}$ are called the *factors* of the series.

A subgroup of $G$ that is a term of some descending series of $G$ is
called a *descendant subgroup* of $G$.

A descending series of $G$ in which all terms are normal in $G$ is
called a *descending normal series*.

Let $\mathfrak{X}$ be a property of groups. A group is said to be
*hypo-$\mathfrak{X}$* if it has a descending normal series whose factors
all have property $\mathfrak{X}$. So, for example, a *hypoabelian group*
is a group that has a descending normal series with abelian factors.
Hypoabelian groups are sometimes called *SD-groups*; they are precisely
the groups that have no non-trivial perfect subgroups, and they are also
precisely the groups in which the transfinite derived series eventually
reaches $\{1\}$.
